_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FACILITY DESCRIPTION
The Poet Biorefining-Cloverdale, facility (formerly Altra Biofuels) is located approximately one mile north northwest of Cloverdale, Indiana (Putnam County). The main product of the Poet Biorefining-Cloverdale facility is denatured ethanol for use as motor vehicle fuel. Production at the facility was initiated in 2007. The plant was shutdown due to market conditions in early 2009.  Poet Biorefining purchased the plant and plans to resume ethanol production in April 2011. POET Biorefining-Cloverdale produces ethanol using the dry mill method. Corn meal is mixed with water and digestive enzymes to produce starch. The resulting mash is converted to fermentable sugars, and yeast is added to ferment the sugars to ethanol.

The fermented mash (beer) contains about 20% alcohol by volume and is distilled, then passed through a dehydration system to produce 200-proof anhydrous ethanol. After final dehydration, the ethanol is collected in two (1,000,000-  gallon each) storage tanks for addition of a denaturant (natural gas condensate, NGC) to make the ethanol unfit for human consumption, per federal and state requirements. The NGC denaturant is normally stored in Tank No. 805, which has a capacity of 60,000 gallons (approximately 380,000 pounds), and may potentially be stored in Tank 802 (180,000 gallons, approximately 1,140,000 pounds). NGC is blended with the 200-proof ethanol via in-line blending and shipped from the facility in tank trucks and rail cars.

CHEMICALS REGULATED UNDER THE EPA CHEMICAL ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM
The NGC denaturant is the only CAPP/RMP regulated chemical present at Poet Biorefining-Cloverdale which exceeds the CAPP quantity thresholds for applicability of the regulation. The CAPP/RMP regulated process consists of the NGC denaturant storage tanks, and the associated blending/transfer equipment and piping. The facility uses in-line blending; thus the two 1,000,000 gallon storage tanks do not contain denatured ethanol. The de

naturant is added to the ethanol to a concentration of 1% to 3%. The greatest CAPP regulated quantity of denaturant in a tank, vessel or piping system is the maximum capacity of the alternate denaturant storage tank (1,140,000 pounds), located in the center containment area of the tank farm.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY AND PROGRAM
POET Biorefining-Cloverdale is committed to the protection of it employees, the surrounding community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process. In the event of an emergency, the POET Biorefining-Cloverdale Emergency Coordinator will direct internal response activities to the extent they are within the qualifications and capabilities of company personnel, taking reasonable precautions to prevent or minimize the extent of release or the co-mingling of materials. There is no facility emergency response team. Employees within their designated work areas will respond to small releases, if such response does not pose a danger to their health or safety. In the event of a larger release, it is the policy of POET Biorefining-Cloverdale to notify the Cloverdale Fire Department and evacuate all employees at the facility.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM & CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
POET Biorefining-Cloverdale is committed to protection of the environment through the combined use of inspection, maintenance, employee training and response preparation. Public access to the facility from the highway is restricted by a gate. Much of the property is fenced, limiting vehicle access. The plant is fully lighted. Personnel are typically on-site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. There is a multi-camera video surveillance system installed at the property, and a general computer based alarm system. The alarm system includes monitoring of the storage tanks and denaturant blending system (level control and overfill monitors). The alarm system is monitored in the control room for abnormal

conditions, which trigger visual control panel alarm lights and audible alarms. All of the facility storage tanks have secondary storage containment and are included in the facility Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
POET Biorefining-Cloverdale has experienced no accidents which require inclusion in the five-year accident history required by Subpart B of the CAPP/RMP regulation.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The POET Biorefining-Cloverdale management team is committed to an on-going system of reviewing changes in available technologies and any plant incidents to identify opportunities to improve plant safety. Planned changes to improve plant safety include building job plans that include hazard identification for all job tasks. The facility plans to install a computer-based maintenance management and tracking system (MAXIMO) which will improve plant safety and equipment reliability.
